b.a: A summary of comparison between gravitation and electrostatics (Linked to textbook Chapter 4)

text.p: Electrostatics and gravitation are very similar because the electrostatic force [mathjaxinline]\mathbf{F}_{e}[/mathjaxinline] also obeys an inverse-square law. In addition, it is also conservative. In the presence of an electric field [mathjaxinline]\mathbf{E}[/mathjaxinline] , in analogy to the gravitational field [mathjaxinline]\vec{\mathbf{g}}[/mathjaxinline] , we define the electric potential difference between two points [mathjaxinline]A\text { and } B[/mathjaxinline] as

where [mathjaxinline]q_{t}[/mathjaxinline] is a test charge. The potential difference [mathjaxinline]\Delta V_{e}[/mathjaxinline] , which we will now denote just by [mathjaxinline]\Delta V[/mathjaxinline] , represents the negative of the work done per unit charge by the electrostatic force when a test charge [mathjaxinline]q_{t}[/mathjaxinline] moves from points A to B. Again, electric potential difference should not be confused with electric potential energy. The two quantities are related as follows. The SI unit of electric potential is volt [mathjaxinline]\lbrack \text {V} ][/mathjaxinline]

When dealing with systems at the atomic or molecular scale, a joule [mathjaxinline]\lbrack \text {J} ][/mathjaxinline] often turns out to be too large as an energy unit.
